At approximately 08:25 BST on Kells Avenue, a 71-year-old man was one of three individuals walking when a red Volkswagen Golf, identified by its southern-registered number plate, stopped beside them. Two men emerged from the vehicle and assaulted two members of the group, stealing a wallet. One assailant also produced a hammer, using it to threaten the men. Police are examining a potential link between this attack and a report of criminal damage to a car on Oramnore Drive occurring concurrently. That incident involved two men in a red car reportedly smashing the windscreen and passenger window of a parked Toyota. Authorities have appealed for witnesses.

Lincolnshire Police intends to recruit approximately 150 new officers over the next two years. The force has largely limited applications to individuals who have resided in the county for at least the preceding 12 months. Marc Jones, the Police and Crime Commissioner for the county, noted the job advertisement had garnered significant interest. Chief Constable Neil Rhodes, in a statement published on the force's website, articulated his wish for the police service to represent the community it serves, with candidates possessing a good understanding of Lincolnshire and the challenges faced by its residents. However, applications from those with strong ties to the county, like armed forces personnel who have relocated, will also be considered. The application process began on Monday. This policy has been labelled "potentially discriminatory" by one employment lawyer, Mary Walker, a partner at Andrew Jackson Solicitors. She stated the force must determine if its locals-only approach is "proportionate" and "legitimate," questioning whether the requirement for local insight outweighs the potential for discriminating against other prospective recruits. Some other police forces across England and Wales employ comparable policies; for instance, the Metropolitan Police has mandated since 2014 that recruits must have lived in London for three of the past six years.

Arsenal FC midfielder Aaron Ramsey, aged 24, recently shared a photograph from his 2014 wedding on June 8th. The image was accompanied by the Welsh caption "un flwyddyn heddiw", which translates to "one year [ago] today".
Although some feedback was positive, a significant number of social media users voiced confusion or even ridicule regarding the message. Critics questioned if the FA Cup winner was "drunk" or had "had a seizure," with much of the backlash attributed to the absence of an English translation.
Specific comments included @RightJudgeIam's query: "Did you lean on the keyboard?" and @BanterousGooner's equally dismissive remark: "Did you have a seizure while typing this or something?" Another user, @MegatronAFC, an "Aaron Ramsey enthusiast," commented sarcastically: "I didn't know Welsh was a language lol."
Following this initial wave of negativity, numerous critical tweets were deleted. A surge of support for Mr. Ramsey emerged on the micro-blogging site, with many users condemning the hostile posts as "horrible." Andrea Williams of Rhymney, posting as @tyclyd1972, passionately defended the use of Welsh, stating: "Why put such horrible status don't be jealous cause we got a different language we r proud to talk Welsh." Ffion Elena also praised Ramsey's action, noting: "Good to see people like @AaronRamsey tweeting in Welsh. Can only be positive for our language."
Mr. Ramsey, who was raised in Caerphilly and attended the Welsh-medium school Ysgol Gyfun Cwm Rhymni prior to joining Cardiff City's youth academy, recently contributed to Wales' vital 1-0 home victory against Belgium on Friday. He has scored nine goals across his 34 appearances for the national team.

In March 2014, 41-year-old Kelly Hewitt was discovered on Teesside's A66, suffering severe head and body injuries consistent with a vehicle impact. Despite the efforts of paramedics and hospital staff, she tragically passed away later that day at Middlesbrough's James Cook University Hospital. A comprehensive police inquiry followed, eventually identifying Clare Bailey, then 26 and also from Middlesbrough, as the driver of a stolen car involved. Bailey was subsequently convicted of causing death by dangerous driving and sentenced to prison, offering some measure of closure to Kelly's grief-stricken family and the Teesside community.

American Troy Bradley and Russian Leonid Tiukhtyaev successfully landed their Two Eagles Balloon, their team announced. They asserted that they had broken world records for distance and duration, having flown for over 137 hours and traveled more than 5,209 miles (8,383km). To officially set new records, the team was required to exceed existing benchmarks by one percent.

In a statement, the Two Eagles team confirmed the balloon's safe descent offshore near La Poza Grande, along the Baja coast. The pilots skillfully guided the craft to a gentle water landing approximately four miles off the Baja coast. The balloon remained stable and inflated, and both pilots were reported to be in good condition.

Their journey commenced in Japan on Sunday, with an initial goal of landing in Canada or the United States. However, unfavorable weather conditions compelled them to alter their trajectory towards Mexico. A Mexican fishing boat subsequently met them at sea.

The statement underscored that a sea landing was permissible according to international rules governing world record establishment. It noted that previous around-the-world attempts, using different balloon types, also concluded with water landings and were validated as records. To surpass the 1981 records by the required one percent, the pilots needed to remain airborne for approximately 138 hours and 45 minutes for duration, and cover around 5,260 miles for distance. The Two Eagles Balloon team specified their landing occurred after "six days, 16 hours and 37 minutes," having covered a remarkable 6,646 miles.

Navigating gas-air balloons proves difficult, as their movement depends on harnessing varying wind speeds and directions at different altitudes. To adjust height, pilots possess only a helium release valve for descent and sandbags to jettison for ascent.

The advanced "Two Eagles" balloon, constructed from a robust Kevlar and carbon-fibre composite, remarkably weighs only 220 pounds (100kg). It is equipped with monitors and other instruments that meticulously track their flight path and collect data for submission to record-keeping authorities. The specially engineered capsule, positioned beneath a massive helium-filled envelope, is designed for flights lasting up to ten days. Within this craft, the pilots occupy a confined, low-ceilinged living space.

Released by RamJam on Thursday, "Southern Rail Tycoon" has already attracted 45,000 players to its satirical world. This light-hearted game challenges players to prevent train guards from boarding, thereby causing service cancellations and allowing them to accrue fictional profits from stranded passengers. Its concept emerged from the widespread service disruptions caused by an RMT industrial dispute over several months. A player faces defeat if enough guards manage to board a train and a previously delayed service finally departs, at which point they are shown a screen depicting plummeting profits and animated, furious commuters swarming a virtual London Victoria station. Developed by Brighton-based indie creator Tom Jackson, operating as RamJam, the game quickly gained viral popularity. Jackson, himself a frequent and exasperated traveler on the Southern Rail network, shared the catalyst for this comedic success: 'Having spent countless hours delayed on platforms, subjected to the taunting departure boards, I felt compelled to transform that annoyance into something productive. What began as a jest among friends evolved into a realization, as I developed 'Southern Rail Tycoon,' that many others could connect with the utter ridiculousness of the situation.'

The game's cynical wit strongly connects with individuals who have firsthand experience of the network's real-world disarray. Players are tasked with strategically deploying an array of comical impediments, such as 'broken signal' notifications and 'leaf on the line' scenarios, all intended to halt guards from reaching their assigned train carriages. Success, measured by a rising 'tycoon' score, is achieved by cancelling more services, symbolizing the player's mock dominance over the troubled railway. Conversely, the game ends abruptly if too many trains depart punctually or if guards manage to board multiple services, causing the player's fictional 'profit margin' to plummet.

Despite its seemingly pessimistic foundation, Tom Jackson emphasizes that the game is intended not as a profound political statement, but instead as a means of catharsis. He articulated, 'It’s about finding levity in a challenging predicament. It’s a form of satire, offering people an opportunity to jest about the disorder rather than merely seethe over it. We've received feedback from users across London, Brighton, and other affected areas, expressing gratitude for being able to transform their frustration into amusement, even if only momentarily.' RamJam is currently exploring future enhancements for 'Southern Rail Tycoon,' including additional scenarios, 'disaster' events, and a possible mobile iteration, which would solidify its place as a beloved pastime for frustrated commuters globally.

Leigh Halfpenny's current contract with Toulon is set to conclude in summer 2016, and reports suggest Cardiff Blues are keen to secure his return. The 26-year-old full-back originally departed the Blues for France in summer 2014. According to Pivac, any returning Welsh player, including Halfpenny, would be considered for discussions if they are serious about coming back to Wales. He emphasized that while budgets are not limitless, the club is always interested in speaking with Welsh players re-entering the market to ascertain their availability and worth.

Should the 2013 British and Irish Lions full-back return to Wales, it would likely be via a national dual contract, with the Welsh Rugby Union contributing 60% of the funding. Under the standing agreement between the WRU and the four Welsh regions, the player's former region is granted the first opportunity to re-sign them, which positions the Blues as the probable frontrunners. However, this protocol isn't absolute, as demonstrated by flanker Dan Lydiate, who chose to join Ospreys instead of his former club, Newport Gwent Dragons, upon his return from Racing 92.

Another significant consideration for Halfpenny could be joining a region that has secured a spot in the 2016-17 European Champions Cup. This season, Scarlets and Ospreys represent Wales in the competition, while the Blues would need to significantly improve their Pro12 performance to qualify for the subsequent season. Given Halfpenny's triumph in the tournament with Toulon last season, participating in Europe's elite club competition could prove a strong incentive.

Following his team's 20-12 Pro12 victory over Zebre, Pivac further stated Scarlets' strong desire to retain club captain Scott Williams. The Welsh international centre, who like Halfpenny is currently recovering from surgery, is on a dual contract set to expire in summer 2016. Pivac expressed hope that Williams would return to play before his contract concludes, adding that while many discussions are underway internally, he couldn't disclose information beyond what was publicly available. He concluded by stressing Williams' vital role as "vice captain" and a key leader, indicating a clear intention to keep him at the club.

Five surveillance cameras have been installed in rural areas across the city in response to persistent illegal waste disposal. Official figures indicate a staggering 29,253 fly-tipping incidents were reported in West Yorkshire in 2023, a concerning statistic that underscores the ongoing issue of unlawful dumping scarring our countryside. These CCTV installations directly address this surge, aiming to both deter culprits and collect vital evidence for prosecution. Steve Hartley, a local environmental enforcement officer, emphasized the importance of these new tools. He stated that each camera is a step towards ensuring accountability for irresponsible individuals. Hartley further noted that fly-tipping costs taxpayers millions annually for cleanup and harms our environment. He expressed hope that these covert cameras will significantly reduce incidents and help authorities identify and prosecute those who degrade our areas, making it clear that these activities will not be permitted.

The former England U-18 international, who first played for the club on the season's last day, is among 17 players nearing the end of their contracts. Burton, 19, told BBC Shropshire that the situation is a waiting game, noting many players' deals are expiring as they were signed two years prior. Rumours have previously connected him to Wolves, Aston Villa, and Glasgow Rangers. However, Burton, a Newport native, has seen how England's top goalkeeper, Joe Hart, also from Shropshire, ascended to prominence, having played a full season as Shrewsbury's keeper ten years ago. He expressed his long-standing connection, stating he "grew up watching the club" and desires to "stay and play for the team as much as I can," acknowledging the uncertainty for all players. Despite feeling a long wait to play, having been at the club since age 10, he couldn't have asked for a "better team" for his debut. The League One side must inform players whose contracts are expiring by May 23rd whether they will be retained. Shrewsbury, finishing 20th, maintained their position in England's third tier by a four-point margin, securing their status on the season's second-to-last weekend. Last week, manager Micky Mellon confirmed he would stay on for the next season, despite the team's narrow escape from relegation.

In Wrexham, specifically Bangor-on-Dee, three individuals were caught in a two-vehicle collision. A separate incident in Carmarthenshire saw one person hospitalized after an accident, while near Welshpool, a vehicle flipped over due to challenging conditions. On the Llanddulas coastal path in Conwy, two cyclists required medical attention after slipping on ice and falling from their bicycles.

Other incidents included a gritting truck overturning in harsh conditions and a school bus skidding on icy roads. Fortunately, the two occupants of the overturned lorry were uninjured. The vehicle came to rest on its side on the B4299, connecting Trelech and Bryn Iwan, on Tuesday evening shortly before 8 PM GMT.

Colin Evans from Carmarthenshire council confirmed that gritting vehicles would continue to be deployed as required. He added that the incident would not affect future gritting efforts, thanks to available reserve vehicles. Evans elaborated that "Gritting crews will stay on main routes until conditions are deemed safe. They will then proceed to secondary routes on elevated terrain, although a swift improvement in conditions is anticipated throughout the morning."

In Wattstown, within Rhondda Cynon Taf, a bus transporting six schoolchildren slid, narrowly avoiding a collision with a wall. Fortunately, no injuries were reported. Angela Slee recounted, "The sole factor preventing the bus from sliding further down the incline was a collection of rocks placed under its wheels by the bus escort." Separately, two individuals required hospital care after a tornado struck their residence.

Hanjin's board unanimously voted on Wednesday to file for court protection, a company spokesman confirmed. This decision follows the company's failure to convince key lenders to reschedule its debt under a new restructuring plan, leading to a severe cash shortage. Hanjin's shares remain suspended in Seoul, having plummeted by as much as 29% on Tuesday. The world's seventh-largest container line, Hanjin has reported unprofitability in four of the last five years.

Some financial reprieve for Hanjin may come from rival Hyundai Merchant Marine (HMM). HMM's shares surged by up to 22% after Korea's financial regulator indicated that the firm might acquire some of Hanjin's assets. Nevertheless, HMM has not been unaffected by the difficulties plaguing the sector, having recently announced its own reorganization strategy.

South Korea's shipping and shipbuilding industries are among those most severely impacted by a prolonged global trade downturn. A decline in orders has resulted in overcapacity, suppressed freight rates, and an escalation of debts. Nomura analyst Young Sun Kwon explained that Korean shipping companies have suffered substantial losses primarily because charter rates for leased vessels were fixed at high levels in 2010, while actual shipping rates have subsequently fallen.

The South Korean government is now preparing to implement a difficult, industry-wide restructuring, which will necessitate significant job cuts. Krystal Tan from Capital Economics stated that this ongoing restructuring is one reason why weak economic growth is anticipated this year and next. She added that the loss of tens of thousands of jobs would certainly negatively affect economic sentiment. However, she believes this number is relatively small when compared to the 26 million people employed in Korea, meaning a large increase in the unemployment rate is unlikely.

The Very Reverend Martin Thrower, the 56-year-old rector of Hadleigh, Suffolk, was accused in Norwich Crown Court of holding his mobile phone over a toilet cubicle. His arrest occurred in August 2016 at an Ipswich shopping centre. At a previous hearing, he pleaded guilty to two charges of voyeurism, receiving a 24-month suspended sentence. As part of his sentence, Thrower was ordered to complete a 60-day course specifically designed to address sex offending behavior, in addition to a further 30-day rehabilitation program.

Prosecutor William Carter explained that the rector was apprehended after a 17-year-old, using a toilet at the Buttermarket shopping centre, heard a sound above him. The teenager observed a hand holding a mobile phone that was filming him over the cubicle partition. He then seized the device, which led directly to Thrower's arrest.

When handing down the sentence, Judge Katharine Moore acknowledged Thrower's generally "well-regarded" status among those he had assisted, describing him as having been a "listening ear" in both "times of great sadness and some in happier times." She stated her perception that his "persistent behavior over a two-year period" had consistently been blamed on a decline in his mental health. While acknowledging his dedication to his work, she firmly rejected the notion that his actions were anything but deliberate choices, made repeatedly in public restrooms when he believed he would not be caught.

Upon his arrest, officers discovered three additional videos on his phone from that same day, two of which captured men seemingly unaware their privacy was being invaded.

Thrower, whose address is Church Street, Hadleigh, Suffolk, serves as the rector for Hadleigh, Layham, and Shelley parishes. The Diocese of St Edmundsbury in Ipswich has suspended him from all his duties. His legal counsel, Stephen Nelson, stated that Thrower was of previous good character and expressed his client's profound remorse.

Colchester United initially took the lead in the 69th minute thanks to Macauley Bonne's goal. However, Chesterfield, despite being reduced to ten men for over 70 minutes, quickly drew level with a penalty. Colchester manager Keen expressed his frustration, stating that teams often become susceptible after scoring, and insisted on significantly improved game management following their eventual 2-1 defeat against Chesterfield.

Keen lamented the infuriating experience of conceding so soon after taking the lead, particularly given their numerical advantage for much of the contest, his disappointment clearly evident. Bonne's excellent finish should have been the crucial moment for them to seal victory and claim all three points. Instead, they suffered a lapse in concentration, allowed the opposition back into contention with ease, and then offered an insufficient response to the eventual winning goal.

While acknowledging the penalty decision was debatable, Keen criticized the team's virtually non-existent reaction to it and the subsequent equalizer. He noted that despite discussions about character and resilience, the team showed very little when it was most needed. Keen demanded a much higher degree of professionalism, focus, and tactical astuteness, emphasizing that every minute of every match is vital, especially in such a competitive division. Their clear shortcomings in concentration and game management led to severe consequences.

This wasn't the first instance of them squandering a strong position, a worrying trend that unequivocally needs to be halted, as it's simply unacceptable. They effectively handed Chesterfield a point, and ultimately, the full three. Greater ruthlessness is required to see games through, encompassing both their offensive approach and, critically, their defensive discipline. While they are creating sufficient scoring opportunities, a positive aspect, they are also conceding avoidable goals, a combination that Keen described as a recipe for disaster. They must become tougher, both physically and mentally, to consistently secure positive results.

Keen views this outcome as a hugely squandered opportunity, potentially costing Colchester United dearly as the season advances. Such lapses in concentration are unaffordable if they aim to climb the league standings and achieve their season's objectives.

Colin Capp, a 23-year-old from Scotland, assaulted Darren Thomas, 45, as he slept in their shared cell on Wing B. Consultant forensic psychiatrist Dr. Melanie Croy informed the jury that Mr. Capp's capacity for sound judgment was compromised by his mental illness. While Mr. Capp admits to causing Mr. Thomas's death, he has pleaded not guilty to murder.

Prosecutor Mr. John Smith QC, addressing the jury, acknowledged Mr. Capp's mental health issues but contended they did not constitute a defense of diminished responsibility or invalidate his intent to kill. He asserted that the brutal nature of the assault on Mr. Thomas, perpetrated while he was vulnerable and unconscious in their cell, clearly indicated intent. Mr. Smith also presented evidence suggesting the attack was pre-meditated.

Under cross-examination, Dr. Croy reiterated her diagnosis that Mr. Capp suffered from paranoid schizophrenia, which severely warped his perception of reality. She detailed his intensifying delusional beliefs within the confined Wing B environment, particularly concerning his cellmate, Mr. Thomas. Dr. Croy explained that while Mr. Capp understood the physical act of killing, his ability to make moral judgments and rational decisions was profoundly impaired. Prison officers corroborated this, describing Mr. Capp's erratic behavior in the days leading up to the incident.

The defense, led by Ms. Sarah Jones, countered that Mr. Capp's actions were a direct consequence of his severe mental illness, which had been inadequately managed within the prison system. Ms. Jones highlighted Dr. Croy's expert testimony, arguing that Mr. Capp's abnormality of mental functioning substantially hindered his ability to comprehend his conduct, form rational judgments, or exercise self-control. She portrayed a young Scottish man whose untreated condition escalated catastrophically, culminating in Darren Thomas's tragic death.

The trial continues, with additional medical testimony anticipated before deliberations begin on the complex interplay between mental health and criminal culpability.

Coastal erosion, driven by weather and waves, causes land to crumble. New research indicates this could result in £1 billion of property loss to the sea in the next century. Ayshah explored Winterton, Norfolk, a significantly affected location, to understand the issue.

An image created by Darren 'Birdie' Bird, showing the Children in Need mascot, Pudsey, tearfully "paying his respects" to Sir Terry Wogan following his passing on Sunday, rapidly circulated across social media. Pudsey is depicted with a tear descending his cheek and holding a microphone, a touching symbol of Sir Terry's instantly recognisable voice and his exceptional commitment to the Children in Need campaign. This digital illustration, a work by Bird, swiftly became a potent visual representation of the country's shared sorrow after the announcement of Sir Terry's death that Sunday. For decades, Sir Terry had embodied the comforting, humorous, and kind voice of Children in Need, leading the annual telethon with his distinctive charisma. This specific portrayal of Pudsey, the much-loved charity bear, openly weeping and clutching a mic, powerfully conveyed the deep feeling of loss experienced by millions who revered Wogan as a national icon. The straightforwardness and emotional depth of Bird's creation led to its continuous sharing across numerous channels, establishing it as a focal point for sincere tributes and collective recollections of the broadcaster's profound influence on public life and his dedicated charitable endeavours. It serves as a strong affirmation of Sir Terry's lasting heritage and the immense admiration he cultivated in countless individuals nationwide.

Vincent Kompany was instrumental in Manchester City taking the lead, pressuring Giorgio Chiellini into an own goal. However, Kompany sustained a calf injury as Juventus fought back to win 2-1. City manager Manuel Pellegrini stated Kompany’s condition would be assessed on Wednesday to determine the severity of the injury. The 29-year-old Kompany was replaced by Nicolas Otamendi, City’s £32.5m signing from Valencia, after Mario Mandzukic equalised for Juventus. Alvaro Morata then scored the winning goal nine minutes from time.

Pellegrini also couldn't start striker Sergio Aguero due to a knee injury sustained during Saturday's win at Crystal Palace. The Argentina international made a seven-minute substitute appearance after City fell behind. Pellegrini explained Aguero was not fit for a full 90 minutes, deeming it too risky to play him extensively due to the potential for re-injury in the same area.

This defeat highlighted a persistent issue for City, who have yet to win their opening Champions League home game in five group stage attempts. Despite this, Pellegrini remains confident of reaching the last 16. Their next two matches are away trips against Germany’s Borussia Monchengladbach and Spain’s reigning Europa League champions, Sevilla.

Pellegrini, who turns 62 on Wednesday, stressed that 15 more points are still available, and qualification depends on their performance and the results of their upcoming matches. He admitted losing at home to a strong side like Juventus was not an ideal start but emphasized that similar situations have occurred previously without preventing their progression.

Raheem Sterling was noted for missing a significant early chance and another when City were 1-0 up. However, Pellegrini downplayed the focus on Sterling, asserting that City had controlled the game. He described it as a "strange game" and felt City played better than Juventus, not deserving to lose. He acknowledged City's failure to convert chances, which is crucial in the Champions League, noting Juventus created fewer opportunities.

West Yorkshire Police confirmed last month that 16,000 traffic tickets issued by police community support officers (PCSOs) were invalid due to an "administrative error." However, the force maintained there was "no basis in law" for issuing refunds, arguing these funds would come "from the public purse." Many drivers had already paid these fines, completely unaware of the underlying issue. This revelation provoked considerable public outrage and anger among those affected, who felt unjustly penalised by the West Yorkshire Police. Drivers expressed significant frustration that the police acknowledged the tickets' invalidity yet simultaneously refused any form of compensation. Legal experts weighed in, questioning the ethical implications of the force retaining money collected illegally, even in the absence of a direct legal precedent for refunds. Some asserted that despite the law not explicitly requiring refunds for such a unique administrative error, the principle of unjust enrichment should apply, preventing one party from benefiting from another's loss caused by their own mistake.

The situation placed substantial pressure on West Yorkshire Police to clarify how such a fundamental mistake occurred and why information about the problem took so long to become public. Critics warned that public trust in the police, particularly regarding the impartiality and accuracy of their enforcement actions, could be severely eroded. The Police and Crime Commissioner for West Yorkshire acknowledged the gravity of the administrative lapse and confirmed that a comprehensive internal review was underway. This investigation aims to understand how PCSOs issued invalid tickets for an extended period without detection, pinpointing weaknesses in internal processes and implementing robust preventative measures.

For the numerous individuals who had already settled their fines, often under duress from potential further penalties or license points, the news was profoundly disheartening. Some indicated intentions to explore collective legal avenues, seeking advice on whether a class-action lawsuit might compel the force to reimburse the payments. Consumer rights organisations also became involved, advocating for affected drivers and calling for clearer legal guidelines to address instances where public body administrative errors result in financial detriment for citizens. The incident exposed a significant systemic flaw, where a clear administrative blunder by West Yorkshire Police left thousands of citizens financially disadvantaged with seemingly no remedy, raising critical questions about accountability and citizen protection in the face of official enforcement. The cost for drivers pursuing individual legal challenges would likely exceed the value of the tickets, further complicating their options. Furthermore, the role of PCSOs and the extent of their powers came under scrutiny following the incident.

Ahmed Mohamed's father, Mohamed El-Hassan Mohamed, has stated he withdrew all his children from schools in the area. According to Mr. Mohamed, the 14-year-old's arrest had a profoundly harmful effect. Ahmed's detention drew significant criticism, and the accusations against him were promptly dismissed. He was apprehended at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, when officials mistook a device he had brought for a "hoax bomb." "I don't want to go to MacArthur," Ahmed's father informed The Dallas Morning News on Tuesday, adding, "These kids won't be content there." Ahmed has received numerous school enrollment offers, his father stated, adding he wanted to give him a break before deciding. The entire family is scheduled to fly to New York on Wednesday, as United Nations dignitaries wish to meet Ahmed. Following that, Mr. Mohamed intends to take his son on a pilgrimage to Mecca in Saudi Arabia. "I pray Allah blesses this time. After that, we'll see," Mohamed commented. Upon their return, they plan to visit the White House to meet U.S. President Barack Obama, he added. Ahmed revealed his intention to transfer schools during a news conference last week. He told reporters it was "very upsetting" his teacher perceived his clock as a danger. "I constructed a clock to impress my teacher, but upon showing it to her, she believed it posed a threat. I am truly saddened that she misunderstood it." The apprehension of Ahmed Mohamed drew extensive condemnation, and the young boy has been met with widespread support, including a White House invitation.

Four individuals have pleaded not guilty to charges related to an alleged attempt to illegally bring 35 people into Tilbury Docks in Essex. Tragically, one person lost his life within the sealed container. Basildon Crown Court was informed that one of the accused had previously been apprehended in France with migrants in his vehicle just 11 days before the Tilbury event. Timothy Murphy, from Londonderry, had been fined £5,000 for this earlier offense in August. Prosecutor Michael Goodwin detailed how on August 16 of the previous year, 35 migrants, among them 15 children, were found inside a container aboard the MV Titania, a vessel that had sailed into Tilbury Docks from Zeebrugge, Belgium. The conditions inside the locked container during the 10-hour journey were characterized as "inhumane and life-threatening," with rapidly rising temperatures and plummeting oxygen levels. It was presented in court that the victims had been intentionally confined within the unit.

Mr. Goodwin elaborated that port authorities noticed unusual sounds emanating from the container. Upon opening it, they discovered individuals who were terrified and distressed, many exhibiting severe symptoms of dehydration and hyperthermia. Among those found was Meet Singh, a 47-year-old man from Afghanistan, who sadly perished during the voyage. A subsequent post-mortem examination determined that his death resulted from a combination of dehydration and hyperthermia.

The prosecution asserts that the four defendants—Stephen McLaughlin (31), Martin McGlinchey (49), Christopher Murphy (20), and Timothy Murphy (33), all residents of Londonderry—were involved in an organized criminal plot to unlawfully bring individuals into the UK for profit. Mr. Goodwin specifically pointed to Timothy Murphy's prior conviction in France, where he was apprehended trying to transport 15 migrants in his truck. This earlier incident, occurring mere days before the tragic event at Tilbury, indicated a well-organized and recurring scheme.

Evidence presented in court showed that the defendants had maintained consistent communication through unregistered "burner" phones, coordinating their activities in the lead-up to the incident. CCTV footage and mobile phone data connected them to the vehicle transporting the container and to areas close to Zeebrugge. The prosecution contended that the defendants were fully cognizant of the perilous conditions the migrants would face and displayed a blatant disregard for human life.

All four accused individuals have entered pleas of not guilty to both the charge of conspiracy to facilitate unlawful entry into the UK and the charge of manslaughter concerning Mr. Singh's death. The trial at Basildon Crown Court is anticipated to continue for several weeks, with more evidence expected to be introduced detailing the planning and execution of the smuggling operation and each defendant's specific involvement. The central focus remains on determining the full extent of their awareness and participation in this tragic occurrence, which ultimately led to one man's death and subjected dozens of others to extreme danger at Tilbury Docks in Essex.

Following a series of unannounced inspections, Chief Inspector of Prisons Peter Clarke released his findings, which presented a nuanced and often challenging picture of the nation's prison system. While some institutions demonstrated notable resilience and effective leadership in difficult circumstances, Clarke's comprehensive report underscored a persistent struggle with systemic issues that continued to undermine the safe and effective operation of many establishments across England and Wales. Among the key challenges identified were significant staff shortages and a concerning increase in the use of new psychoactive substances, both of which contributed directly to more unpredictable and violent behavior among the inmate population. Despite evidence of a decline in safety standards since 2013, the inspections also revealed positive aspects, including strong staff-prisoner relationships and a commendably broad range of training and educational opportunities. Overall, Mr Clarke characterized the situation as a "mixed picture of progress," yet the surge in violence, often directly linked to the ready availability of illicit drugs like 'spice,' undeniably placed immense strain on both existing resources and the morale of the dedicated staff members.

A particularly significant challenge highlighted by Clarke was the ongoing and critical issue of staff retention. This problem, greatly exacerbated by the inherently demanding and often dangerous work environment within prisons, meant that many facilities struggled considerably to deliver a full daily regime. This often resulted in prisoners experiencing extended periods of lock-up, with significantly reduced time outside of their cells. Such limited out-of-cell time invariably fueled frustration and further escalated tensions within environments already inherently volatile. Furthermore, the report critically drew attention to the fundamental problem of prison capacity. A substantial number of establishments were found to be operating significantly above their certified normal accommodation levels. This widespread and severe overcrowding, where cells originally designed for a single inmate were frequently forced to house two, or even three, directly contributed to the documented decline in overall safety and a notable increase in violent incidents. This situation severely limited personal space for inmates, inevitably heightened friction between them, and made effective supervision by staff considerably more difficult and resource-intensive.

Peter Clarke forcefully underscored the urgent need for substantial and sustained investment, not solely in the physical infrastructure and fabric of prisons, but, more critically, in the comprehensive recruitment, ongoing retention, and overall well-being of all frontline staff. He adamantly emphasized that prioritizing the mental and physical health of both prisoners and the dedicated staff was absolutely essential for cultivating environments genuinely conducive to long-term rehabilitation, rather than those merely focused on basic containment. The Chief Inspector issued a clear warning: without decisively tackling these deep-seated structural issues, which fundamentally include the growing mismatch between the continually rising prison population and the available certified normal accommodation, the risk of further profound deterioration in safety and order within the nation's prisons would regrettably remain unacceptably high. His comprehensive findings provided a sobering and stark assessment, which strongly urged the government to adopt a coherent, strategic, and far-reaching approach to adequately resource, manage, and ultimately safeguard the future integrity of the entire prison system.

Due to the upcoming general elections in India, commencing on May 12, the Twenty20 competition's schedule has been adjusted, as security personnel will be occupied. The initial phase of the tournament, from April 16 to April 30, will see a minimum of 16 matches played in the UAE. Following this, some second-stage fixtures are slated for Bangladesh. Once polling concludes, specifically from May 13, the competition will relocate to India for the remaining league games and play-offs. The IPL has requested government permission to host these later matches in various Indian states after their respective election phases end. The third and final phase, starting May 12 in India, will notably avoid May 16, which is designated for vote counting and election results. This scheduling change mirrors the 2009 IPL, which took place in South Africa due to electoral conflicts that year.

A life-sized bronze statue of Pocahontas stands in Gravesend, Kent, where she passed away in 1617 while journeying back to Virginia. Historic England has reaffirmed its Grade II listed status for this effigy, updating information regarding her life and role in Transatlantic history within its heritage list.

Furthermore, a monument in London has also been granted Grade II listed status. The Virginia Quay First Settlers Monument, situated in Blackwall across the River Thames from the O2 arena, commemorates the men, women, and children who set sail from that quayside for North America in December 1606. These adventurers subsequently founded Jamestown, Virginia, the first English colony, in April 1607, led by John Smith.

The statue of Pocahontas is a reproduction of a sculpture found in Jamestown, Virginia, which the state's then-governor donated to the UK in 1958. It was first officially listed in 1975.

Debbie Mays, Historic England's head of listing, commented, "Pocahontas is remembered for fostering connections between two vastly different cultures. These monuments act as physical reminders of her story, that of the English venturing to the New World, and our shared colonial past, and we are pleased to recognize their importance on the National Heritage List for England."

The team experienced a seven-wicket loss, having been dismissed for a mere 90 runs in a rain-shortened match at the Riverside. Speaking to BBC Newcastle, 29-year-old Rushworth confessed their performance was significantly inadequate. He acknowledged the reduced overs, but stressed that being bowled out for 90 in 22 overs was simply "not good enough." The squad has accepted that adjustments are necessary, either in their strategic approach or training methods. A four-and-a-half-hour rain interruption saw the game curtailed to 22 overs per side. This total was Durham's lowest against Worcestershire since they attained first-class county status in 1992. Mark Stoneman (29) and Paul Collingwood (17) were the sole batsmen to reach double figures. Sunderland-born Rushworth commented that while bowling conditions were favorable, batters must find ways to navigate difficult periods and accumulate runs. He highlighted the importance of consolidation over consistently attempting aggressive shots. To successfully pursue and overcome opponents, he stated, they "have to be able to put scores on the board." Durham's next fixture is Wednesday against Nottinghamshire. Rushworth added that alterations are vital, as Nottinghamshire have scored over 400 in their recent two games.

Updated 31 March 2015, 18:32 BST. Millie from Millie Inbetween hosts, exploring why our physical appearance is so important to many. Four children engage in an activity to assess their self-perception, while popstar Meghan Trainor shares her struggles with body image concerns. Explore more Newsround special programmes.

Surveys by St Andrews University's Sea Mammal Research Unit (SMRU), commissioned by Scottish Natural Heritage (SNH), indicate fewer seals on Scotland's east coast and in Orkney. Overall, sightings of harbour (or common) seals have been declining for several years, a trend confirmed by the latest research. A survey in 2008 counted 2,687, highlighting a significant drop since. For example, Aberlady Bay in East Lothian recorded 213 seals, down from 459 seven years prior. The Firth of Tay and Eden Estuary Special Area of Conservation saw its lowest figure yet with 50 seals, compared to a previous 78. In Orkney, 1,865 seals were recorded, a decrease from 2,687 in 2010. Time constraints prevented the unit from surveying the coast from Aberlady Bay to the Scottish Borders. Conversely, the west coast showed a rise in harbour seal numbers, with 1,095 found between Cape Wrath and Ullapool.

"This Is For My Girls" was composed by Diane Warren, renowned for her previous hits such as "I Don't Want To Miss A Thing" and "Un-Break My Heart." She described the song, a forceful "girl power" anthem, as a blend of "We Are the World meets Lady Marmalade." Obama released the single ahead of her keynote address at the SXSW festival, where she will discuss her 'Let Girls Learn' initiative, aimed at boosting education rates among adolescent girls globally. Following her speech, she will participate in a panel on the initiative alongside several of the song's performers, including Missy Elliott and Diane Warren, joined by Sophia Bush and moderator Queen Latifah.

Musically, "This Is For My Girls" features energetic horn accents and a driving drum beat, creating a somewhat militaristic feel. Its lyrics largely consist of familiar empowerment phrases—for instance, "Don't take nothing from nobody," "It's all about respect," and "Stand strong forever"—which have been common in female-led R&B since the early 2000s. Additional vocalists on the track include Janelle Monae, "Glee" actress Lea Michele, Disney star Zendaya, 16-year-old Motown artist Jadagrace, and Beyoncé's mentees Chloe & Halle. All participating artists waived their fees, ensuring proceeds benefit the 'Let Girls Learn' campaign directly.

Warren told Billboard that "We haven't had an anthem like this in a while," explaining her vision for the record involved "all these different women, never just one girl singing on it." She further remarked that "With Kelly Rowland on it, it's almost like an updated Destiny's Child record," and voiced her hope that it "can be a huge worldwide anthem." The single is exclusively available on iTunes, and Obama's SXSW speech will be live-streamed on makers.com from 16:00 GMT.

Heavyweight boxing champion Tyson Fury, 27, known for his opinions on women, abortion, and homosexuality, has been summoned to a meeting with the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) early next year. The BBBofC decided this after a Wednesday discussion. Fury denies being homophobic, asserting he is "uniting the world," though no precise date for the meeting has been set.

Meanwhile, Fury will not face criminal charges from Greater Manchester Police (GMP) regarding alleged homophobic remarks. GMP received a complaint about his statements on the BBC's Victoria Derbyshire programme but classified them as a "hate incident" rather than a "hate crime."

Following his victory over Wladimir Klitschko in Dusseldorf, Fury stated: "I'm not sexist. I believe a woman's best place is in the kitchen and on her back. That's my personal belief. Making me a good cup of tea, that's what I believe." The new world champion had also previously claimed that the legalisation of paedophilia, alongside the decriminalisation of homosexuality and abortion, would signal "the devil come home." Subsequently, the Manchester-born fighter clarified, "Tyson Fury loves his fellow humans. He doesn't hate anybody."

Greg Rutherford, a fellow nominee for BBC Sports Personality of the Year and a long jump champion, initially intended to withdraw from the event due to Fury's comments but later changed his mind. Furthermore, Fury, who captured the WBA, IBF, and WBO titles on November 28 by defeating Klitschko, was stripped of his IBF belt on Tuesday. This occurred because he opted for a rematch with Klitschko instead of fulfilling the IBF's mandatory defence against Ukrainian Vyacheslav Glazkov.

Fifty-year-old McAuley, residing at Cavan Bank Walk, Ballyconnell, County Cavan, admitted guilt to two charges stemming from an incident on December 24 last year. He pleaded guilty to brandishing a knife during an altercation in Kilderry, Kilnaleck, Cavan, and to issuing death threats against his estranged wife’s brother, Tommy Tully, during the same event. McAuley's only words were confirming his guilt. The judge ordered McAuley held at Castlerea prison until his sentencing hearing at Cavan Circuit Court on November 24. Furthermore, the court requested a victim impact report for Ms Tully and a probation and welfare report for McAuley.

Ashley Broomhall recently completed challenging mountain climbs, first scaling 3,560ft (1,085m) Snowdon in Snowdonia before undertaking the 4,406ft (1,344m) Ben Nevis near Fort William, Scotland. The ascent and descent of Ben Nevis took him seven hours. He now plans to hike 3,208ft (978m) Scafell Pike in the Lake District.

Mr. Broomhall, a 28-year-old from Whitchurch in Shropshire, is tackling these peaks to generate funds for Cancer Research UK, a personal mission inspired by his mother's cancer diagnosis. For over five years, he has been a member of the 501st UK Garrison, a Star Wars costuming club whose members attend events across the UK in "movie-accurate" outfits to raise money for various charities.

For his summer ascents of Snowdon and Ben Nevis, Mr. Broomhall adapted his Imperial stormtrooper costume for improved flexibility during the climbs. Prioritizing safety, he opted for regular walking boots instead of his costume footwear, which was unsuitable for the demanding terrain, and was accompanied by friends.

While climbing Ben Nevis, Scotland's highest Munro and Britain's tallest mountain, dressed as a stormtrooper and proudly carrying a UK Garrison flag, Mr. Broomhall garnered significant attention. He noted that other climbers were often bewildered by the sight of a stormtrooper on the mountain, an unexpected encounter. He handed out cards explaining his purpose, receiving enthusiastic support and donations from fellow trekkers.

Higher on Ben Nevis, he navigated through sections of thigh-deep snow. At one of these snowy expanses, he and his walking companion engaged in a playful snowball fight with other hikers. Upon reaching the final snowfield that led to the summit, Mr. Broomhall described a surge of pride as he charged forward with the flag. Greeted by cheers from climbers already there, he triumphantly planted his flag, symbolically claiming the summit for the "Empire." He expressed his enjoyment of the challenge and his affection for Scotland and its Munros, declaring his intention to conquer Scafell Pike also in his distinctive armour, having successfully done so for the first two peaks.

Dungannon's Kris Meeke, driving a Citroen, secured victory in three of the four stages during the Tour de Corse. Sébastien Ogier remained close behind Meeke, who aims to follow up his dramatic Rally Mexico win with another triumph. Thierry Neuville of Hyundai sits in third place, trailing the leader by 25.8 seconds.

Meeke asserted his dominance early in the season's first asphalt round, winning the opening stage and adding two more victories before day's end. Four-time world champion Ogier, in his M-Sport Ford, was fastest in SS3, reducing Meeke's lead to just over eight seconds. However, Meeke responded in the final stage, pushing his advantage beyond 10 seconds.

Meeke, aged 37, expressed satisfaction, remarking, "It's been a good day." He acknowledged the constant pressure from "Seb," stating, "You always have to be wary of Seb, because he never gives up. But I'm comfortable with my pace, so let's see how we go on Saturday." Meanwhile, Meeke's Citroen teammate, Craig Breen from Waterford, holds an impressive fourth position, currently engaged in a close contest with Spanish competitor Dani Sordo.

Merseyrail intends to launch a new fleet of 52 trains, designed for driver-only operation (DOO), starting in 2020. The company stated that no permanent guards or guard managers would face compulsory termination of their employment. The RMT union, however, announced it was in a formal dispute with Merseyrail, indicating its 220 members would be balloted for strike action. John Tilley, an RMT representative, stated that Merseyrail failed to provide solid assurances regarding the future of 220 guards and managers during a meeting on Wednesday, expressing his strong expectation that members would vote overwhelmingly for industrial action. RMT General Secretary Mick Cash affirmed the union's refusal to accept any expansion of DOO, committing to a fight to preserve the guard's crucial safety role and ensure a guard remains on every train. He added that the train operator had "snubbed" a final opportunity to prevent the ballot. Cash further commented that the situation was "entirely preventable if the company had listened to the union's profound safety concerns... and had prioritized passenger safety over profit." Merseyrail, for its part, asserted it had "made it clear" it would support guards and management whose positions would cease to exist with the new fleet's introduction, confirming there would be no compulsory redundancies. The train operator explained that while the RMT had insisted on a guard on every new train, the new fleet was designed to operate without guards, making it impossible for them to fulfill this demand. Merseyrail's existing fleet, although based on designs from the 1950s, is nearly 40 years old.

Scotland's Anderson delivered an outstanding average of 107.68 – the highest recorded in the tournament so far – surpassing his Dutch opponent Raymond van Barneveld's 102.3 in a thrilling quarter-final. The two darting legends collectively registered 20 maximum 180s at London's Alexandra Palace, in what many declared one of the greatest matches ever witnessed in World Darts Championship history. This captivating encounter saw both competitors deliver exceptional performances, brilliantly demonstrating their legendary skill and unwavering determination on the sport's grandest stage. Anderson, a two-time world champion, unequivocally proved his standing as one of darts' all-time greats, maintaining incredible consistency and pin-point accuracy despite intense pressure. Van Barneveld, himself a five-time world champion, vigorously challenged 'The Flying Scotsman' throughout the match, thrilling the packed crowd with his classic form and dramatic scoring surges. The electric ambiance at 'Ally Pally' heightened the tension of every throw, as fans vociferously applauded the elite-level play from start to finish. This monumental showdown, ultimately won by Anderson after a hard-fought contest, has firmly etched its place in darts' annals, establishing a new benchmark for both individual and cumulative scoring in the esteemed competition. Anderson's dominant showing now positions him as a leading contender for the semi-finals, while Van Barneveld's valiant display served as a powerful reminder of his enduring class and ability to perform at the very peak of the sport.

Glenfield Hospital's East Midlands Congenital Heart Centre is set to discontinue its children's surgical services, an announcement made on Wednesday. This decision stems from a national review of ten units, aiming to consolidate specialist expertise into fewer locations. The charity Heartlink swiftly expressed its opposition to this judgement. John Rigby, a Heartlink spokesman, stated their intention to "take stock, listen to what our reps have to say and be guided by them," vowing to "fight to do our very best to keep children's services here [at Glenfield]."

Annually, the centre performs around 230 operations on children and 70 on adults. It also boasts the UK's largest ECMO unit, which provides partial cardiopulmonary bypass to oxygenate the blood of critically ill patients. Although pediatric surgeries will cease, the unit will remain open for patient diagnosis, monitoring, and non-surgical treatments.

Serving a population of approximately five million, the centre's closure means the next comparable facility is in Birmingham, roughly 40 miles (64.4 km) away. Leslie Hamilton, vice-chair of the Safe and Sustainable review's steering group, articulated the surgical community's concern that expertise was too thinly spread across the country. He explained the rationale for consolidation: "We felt we had to concentrate the expertise and reduce the number of centres in the country so we could have bigger centres with bigger surgical teams. That would lead to sustainable care for the future and also a big improvement in care."

Tony Fowlston's three-year-old son, Lewis, has been a patient at Glenfield. The family regularly travels about 60 miles (96.5 km) from Boston, Lincolnshire, to access specialists. Mr. Fowlston highlighted that further travel could pose a serious risk, given Lewis recently suffered a cardiac arrest shortly after arriving at Glenfield. He critically questioned the alternative: "He could have had that cardiac arrest on the way to, say, Birmingham. Could he have had the same service in the back of an ambulance? I very much doubt it." A petition to save the unit garnered more than 100,000 signatures.

Hina Rabbani Khar's statements emerged shortly after the militaries of both nations reached an agreement to reduce escalating tensions, following a meeting between their operational chiefs. The recent surge in cross-border violence last week, marked by fatal clashes, has propelled these neighbors into their most severe diplomatic crisis since the 2008 Mumbai attacks, which India attributes to militants operating from Pakistan. Khar's crucial message stressed the necessity for both military and political figures to exercise restraint and engage in substantive dialogue to ease tensions along the Line of Control, rather than resorting to aggressive declarations. The deadly border incidents of the past week have undeniably pushed these nuclear-armed states to the verge of a perilous confrontation, echoing the intense hostility observed after the 2008 Mumbai attacks, for which India holds Pakistan-based militants directly responsible.

Consequently, Hina Rabbani Khar's observations hold considerable importance during this pivotal moment. Her past experience as a leading diplomat lends authority to her appeal for tranquility and for upholding the established de-escalation protocols, thereby reinforcing the diplomatic route. Ms. Khar's insistence on pursuing a peaceful settlement, as opposed to engaging in provocative language or military displays, underscores the necessity for a continuous endeavor to cultivate mutual trust and avert further border fatalities. The immediate priority must be to guarantee that the understanding forged by the chiefs of operations is thoroughly honored and executed, thus fostering a more stable regional atmosphere. Both countries are urged to place their citizens' welfare above nationalistic rhetoric, striving for a future where recurring crises do not jeopardize regional harmony. Furthermore, the global community bears a responsibility to motivate both India and Pakistan to sustain open communication channels and resolve their fundamental disagreements peacefully, preventing localized border incidents from escalating uncontrollably.

Dave Cormack, who previously served as Aberdeen's chief executive, recently sold his software company for £630 million. He informed the Aberdeen website that he would contribute both financially and with his time, aiming to draw in US investment and form strategic alliances to help the club reach its full potential. Cormack will collaborate with the current board, including chairman Stewart Milne, dividing his time between Atlanta and North East Scotland. The 58-year-old previously held an interim chief executive role at Pittodrie from 2000 to 2001, while on a break from his business ventures in the United States. He intends to work alongside the AFC management team to implement innovative strategies he's observed succeeding in the US. His return follows the sale of a software company he significantly expanded, growing its team from 12 employees in 2004 to 500 by 2016, and generating £107 million in yearly revenue. Cormack stated his honor at rejoining the board, noting he had consistently supported and advised the club for years. He commended the dedication of everyone at Pittodrie, evidenced by the club's strong performance both athletically and administratively in recent seasons. He acknowledged the fortunate position of having a high-performing, debt-free team, but stressed the necessity of capitalizing on opportunities to boost income and expand the fanbase. He expressed eagerness to collaborate with the current leadership team, with whom he shares a strong rapport. Cormack is confident that, working together and with fan support, they can enhance the club's financial standing, enlarge its supporter base, and develop a modern community stadium and training complex, enabling AFC to effectively leverage developments in European club competitions. Chairman Stewart Milne expressed his welcome for Cormack's engagement and the wealth of experience he brings. Milne highlighted the growing complexity of managing a modern football club, stating that Dave's expertise, background, enthusiasm, and dedication would be highly advantageous. He added that Cormack offers fresh insights, an innovative methodology, and valuable business acumen to confront current challenges directly.

Authorities suspect a female Islamic State suicide bomber was responsible for the explosion. This attack comes as Turkey intensifies its efforts against militants, a shift from past accusations of inaction. The explosion provoked violent demonstrations in Istanbul, where police deployed water cannons, teargas, and rubber bullets. The bomb, which occurred on a Friday, targeted young activists preparing to travel to Syria to assist in the reconstruction of Kobane. Footage reveals the group, predominantly university-aged individuals, at a cultural center's grounds holding a press conference about their initiative when the blast occurred. They were chanting slogans and displaying a banner proclaiming, "We defended it together, we are building it together." Kobane, situated across the border from Suruc, was a scene of intense conflict between IS and Kurdish forces, with Kurds reclaiming it in January. Suruc currently hosts numerous refugees who escaped the violence in Kobane. The attack occurred shortly before noon local time (09:00 GMT), injuring approximately one hundred people. Prime Minister Davutoglu stated that preliminary evidence pointed to IS as the perpetrators. Addressing a news conference in Ankara, he affirmed Turkey's ongoing commitment to implement all essential counter-terrorism measures against Islamic State. He emphasized confronting a "terrorism incident" and the determination to identify and punish those accountable, also indicating an increase in security measures along the Syrian border. BBC Middle East correspondent Jim Muir notes that Turkey, widely criticized for previously overlooking IS operations, has recently intensified its efforts against the militants, which could be a motive for the assault. He anticipates that Turkish leadership will likely adopt an even stricter stance following this event. Widespread demonstrations erupted in cities nationwide. Protests in Istanbul and Ankara escalated into violence, resulting in clashes with police. According to a Reuters witness, hundreds of Istanbul protestors chanted slogans alleging Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's cooperation with IS. Earlier, while in Cyprus, the President denounced the attack, stating, "On behalf of my people, I curse and condemn the perpetrators of this brutality." He added that "Terror must be condemned no matter where it comes from." A White House spokesperson also condemned the attack, expressing "solidarity with the Turkish government and the Turkish people."

Around 1:45 PM BST, the Welsh Ambulance Service received a 999 emergency call detailing an incident on Merthyr Road, Merthyr, requiring immediate attention. Personnel were swiftly dispatched to the site, located near Prince Charles Hospital, to assess and treat a patient. The service consistently prioritizes such urgent calls to safeguard community safety and well-being.

An RAF Voyager A330 aircraft, primarily used for air-to-air refuelling, is slated for a refurbishment costing approximately £10 million. The government justifies this expenditure by asserting it will yield annual savings of around £775,000, making the plane a more economical choice than continually chartering flights. However, Stewart Hosie of the Scottish National Party (SNP) has called for "absolute transparency" to guarantee the most advantageous arrangement for taxpayers.

Mr. Hosie's call for complete openness underscores the necessity for rigorous oversight. He expressed skepticism regarding the £10 million investment against the projected £775,000 yearly savings, demanding thorough examination of its long-term financial viability. The refitting, which includes interior alterations for VIP transportation, has attracted criticism. Nevertheless, proponents contend that an RAF Voyager A330 offers superior security, operational flexibility, and availability for travel by ministers and the Prime Minister compared to commercial charter services.

The government's rationale centers on achieving enduring economic advantages and bolstering operational autonomy. The £10 million initial outlay is expected to be recouped through these savings over roughly 13 years. Utilizing an existing military asset instead of private jet charters simplifies logistical arrangements for sensitive assignments. This approach also endows the RAF Voyager A330, originally a refuelling platform, with invaluable dual-use capabilities, thereby maximizing its cost-effectiveness within the defence budget.

A spokesperson from the Ministry of Defence highlighted the exceptional value delivered by this initiative. The modification allows the aircraft to continue its fundamental military responsibilities when not transporting VIPs, thereby negating the need for a separate, dedicated executive jet. This adaptable, multi-role strategy is fundamental to an efficient defence infrastructure. Acknowledging the legitimate concerns raised by the SNP, particularly those of Stewart Hosie, the government committed to full disclosure regarding project costs and progress. This commitment aims to dispel notions of a "vanity project" and reaffirm its dedication to fiscal prudence. Ultimately, the objective is to provide the Prime Minister and senior officials with secure, economical travel solutions, seamlessly integrated with existing military resources, ensuring the RAF Voyager A330 remains a vital component for national security and state functions.

In a recent Sunday Times article, the Plaid Cymru leader urged Wales to adopt a unified stance. A forthcoming debate will pit the UKIP leader against the Welsh First Minister on the contentious subjects of Wales's future within the United Kingdom and its post-Brexit relationship with the European Union. Ms Wood's plea for solidarity highlights her party's apprehension that, without a robust and coherent Welsh voice, the nation's interests could be overlooked during negotiations with both the UK Government and Brussels. She underscored the importance of safeguarding Welsh employment, key industries, and funding streams, advocating for a customized agreement tailored to Wales's distinct economic and social context. Conversely, the UKIP leader is anticipated to promote a swift and complete departure from the EU, arguing that this would unlock substantial opportunities for Welsh prosperity and greater autonomy. This impending discussion reveals significant political divisions across Wales concerning its path forward, a sharp contrast to Ms Wood's call for a unified approach to ensure Wales's perspective is effectively conveyed amid the complexities of a changing UK.

The 19-year-old Harry Dearden and Paul Horton (41) forged an 85-run opening partnership before Glamorgan swiftly claimed three wickets, two of which were taken by young Lukas Carey. Dearden then spearheaded a valuable 90-run stand with Mark Pettini (who remained 63 not out) until spinner Andrew Salter dismissed him. Under the floodlights, Pettini then guided the Foxes to secure their second batting point. Despite being dropped when he had just one run and narrowly escaping two potential run-outs, Dearden’s resilient vigil lasted 211 balls. This was a gritty batting display from the home side, who were asked to bat first in a contest between two teams that had both suffered significant defeats in their opening two fixtures. Salter secured his second wicket, bowling Cameron Delport for 20, after which Pettini and Lewis Hill rapidly added 73 runs, capitalising on the new ball.

Speaking to BBC Radio Leicester, Leicestershire’s Harry Dearden commented: "I'm incredibly proud of achieving my career-best score. While I had hoped to reach a century, I'm still very proud of this performance, which has made it a truly positive day for us. The conditions were challenging early on, with the ball moving off the pitch and swinging. The key was to face as many deliveries as possible to settle in, and it was a tough contest against their opening bowlers. My focus was on digging deep and maintaining maximum discipline. Batting with Horts (Paul Horton) is beneficial as his experience provides a calming influence, and it's also excellent to bat alongside Mark (Pettini) because he helps you stay balanced."

Glamorgan spinner Andrew Salter shared his thoughts with BBC Wales Sport: "I'm pleased to have taken those two wickets, though it wasn't surprising that there wasn't much spin – one delivery went straight through, and the other, a bit fuller, found some rough. My primary aim was to control the scoring rate, believing that sustained pressure would eventually yield rewards. Therefore, I hope my services won't be required significantly more in this first innings. Overall, our bowling unit performed exceptionally well for most of the day; Lukas (Carey) was outstanding at the start. The run-rate was kept to 2.6 for a significant portion of the day, and it was only towards the close that they managed to increase their scoring."

The 27-year-old former England youth international, who left Sunderland last season, previously played for Chelsea and Everton. Royals boss Kelly Chambers hailed her as "a truly exciting signing." Chambers added, "She's a prolific scorer who will definitely enhance our attacking options and perfectly suits our style of play."

The concept for the event reportedly emerged at 2 PM. Following intense speculation and several location changes, tickets for the Koko venue in Camden became available at 7 PM. Despite waiting for hours in the cold, the audience didn't see Kanye perform until approximately 1:20 AM. He was accompanied onstage by Skepta, JME, Novelist, Vic Mensa, Meridian Dan, Raekwon, and Cyhi. Radio 1's Clara Amfo, who attended, described the scene as "ridiculous," with "hordes of people outside," calling it "crazy." Access to the venue for fans began around 12:45 AM, though Kanye's performance didn't commence until over half an hour later. Grimmy expressed disappointment at missing the event, citing his need to "get up and do the radio [Radio 1 breakfast show]." Nevertheless, he admired its spontaneous nature, commenting, "I love that it was like, panic, it's exciting it's tonight." Clara informed Grimmy that Kanye "smashed it." She added that "He's like trolling the UK right now and I totally fell for it." Beyond performing classic hits such as "Jesus Walks" and "Clique," he also gave a sneak peek of his latest collaboration with Vic Mensa. Mistajam from 1Xtra was also in attendance, tweeting, "Tonight will go down in history." For more updates, follow @BBCNewsbeat on Twitter and Instagram, and Radio1Newsbeat on YouTube.

It was a momentous occasion as the Commonwealth gold medallist, Josh Taylor, competed before his local supporters for the first time at a packed Meadowbank. "I hadn't anticipated such a swift conclusion," Taylor remarked to BBC Scotland after the bout. His manager, Barry McGuigan, lauded him, stating, "This young man is exceptionally gifted. We must ensure he takes on the appropriate challenges at the right junctures in his career."

His Hungarian opponent, Mate, entered the ring boasting an impressive track record of 17 victories from 22 contests. However, from the opening bell, it became clear that Mate was in for an arduous night. Taylor, renowned for his explosive power and strategic boxing, wasted no time in asserting his command. He moved with fluid precision, expertly cutting off the ring and delivering sharp, precise jabs that quickly flushed Mate’s face. The Edinburgh faithful, already charged with anticipation, erupted with cheers with every successful strike. Taylor’s southpaw stance, coupled with his formidable left hand, proved particularly challenging for Mate, who struggled to establish any rhythm or land any notable counters.

Less than a minute into the fight, a rapid-fire combination from Taylor—a left hook immediately followed by a straight right—sent Mate reeling back into the ropes. The Commonwealth champion, sensing an imminent finish, intensified his assault with relentless aggression. Mate displayed admirable fortitude, attempting to clinch and absorb the barrage, but Taylor's accuracy and volume of punches were simply overwhelming. Just past the midpoint of the initial round, a perfectly timed left uppercut from Taylor snapped Mate’s head back, followed by a devastating right hook that floored the visiting fighter.

The referee promptly initiated the count as Mate valiantly attempted to regain his footing, his gaze unfocused. Although he managed to rise at the count of nine, his legs were visibly unstable, prompting the referee to judiciously halt the match, deeming him unfit to continue. The official time of the stoppage was a mere 2 minutes and 10 seconds into the first round, a truly dominant and destructive display from the Prestonpans native. The capacity crowd at Meadowbank Arena erupted in a thunderous roar, rising in a standing ovation for their local hero.

Post-fight, a beaming Taylor relished the fervent adoration of the crowd, acknowledging their unwavering backing. Later, in an interview with BBC Scotland, he reflected on the win, reiterating his surprise at how quickly it unfolded. "I came prepared for a tough encounter, perhaps a few rounds to warm up, but I connected cleanly early on and just went for it. The fan support was incredible; it truly motivated me."

Manager Barry McGuigan, the esteemed former world champion, observed with immense satisfaction. "Tonight, Josh unequivocally demonstrated why we believe he's destined for greatness," McGuigan informed reporters. "His power, speed, and ring IQ are all exceptional. He flawlessly managed the pressure of fighting at Meadowbank in front of his home crowd. This was a definitive victory, sending a clear message to the super-lightweight division. We are not rushing anything; as I've stated before, we must select the correct fights at the optimal times to ensure his proper development. However, he is learning and advancing with each bout. We will analyze this performance and meticulously plan his next move. Significant challenges await Josh, and he is ready to face them. This performance merely confirms that he is indeed a very special talent, capable of reaching the pinnacle of the sport." This triumph marked another pivotal moment in Taylor's rapidly ascending professional journey, paving the way for even greater challenges and unequivocally establishing his quality on home soil against a respectable opponent, despite the brevity of the contest. The excitement surrounding Taylor intensified significantly after this commanding showing at Meadowbank, firmly cementing his status as one of Scotland's most thrilling boxing prospects, a future champion in the making, building upon his past Commonwealth Games achievements.

Romelu Lukaku, the 24-year-old Belgian striker, a £75 million signing from Everton, secured the winning goal seven minutes before the half-time whistle. This came after Henrikh Mkhitaryan had previously equalised, following United falling behind just 20 minutes into the match. The team then suffered further difficulties with Juan Mata's injury and Antonio Valencia's sending off.

Regarding Lukaku's decisive strike, Mourinho commented, "It's pleasing for him personally, but for me, it holds less significance." He reiterated, "I conveyed to him that the crucial aspect is the team's collective achievement, securing the three points, not his individual goal count. While his goal was indeed vital, it was scored in a game marked by considerable adversities, including conceding first, Mata's injury, and Valencia's red card. Such moments truly test a team's resilience, and I'm satisfied with our fighting spirit to clinch the victory, though we must learn from the mistakes that led to these challenging situations."

Mata's injury is a major concern. "He is an essential player for us, and his creative influence will be sorely missed. We will ascertain the full extent of the injury, but it appeared serious," Mourinho stated. Addressing Valencia's red card, he described it as an "unnecessary act of indiscipline which he acknowledges. An experienced player should avoid such an error, leaving his side with ten men and missing the subsequent fixture. We cannot afford these kinds of lapses if we aim to contend for significant honours."

"Romelu understands my high expectations, which extend beyond merely scoring goals to encompass his entire contribution," Mourinho continued. "I expect him to engage in link-up play, press defenders from the front, and be constantly involved in our attacking build-up, rather than simply waiting for scoring opportunities. Goals are a natural outcome of executing all other aspects correctly. He possesses the potential to develop into a complete forward for Manchester United, and we will persist in refining every facet of his game."

The team demonstrated remarkable character to secure the win despite numerous setbacks, including the initial deficit. "However, the overall performance wasn't flawless," Mourinho noted. "We allowed them excessive space at times and needed to be more clinical to settle the game sooner. We must show consistent improvement. We'll take the three points, meticulously analyse areas for betterment, and immediately shift our focus to the upcoming fixture. With a protracted season ahead, every player must sustain concentration, uphold discipline, and consistently produce top-tier performances devoid of detrimental mistakes."

A Royal Air Force plane from the Rhodesian Squadron, stationed at RAF Wittering, crashed in Holme on November 22, 1940. Pilot Officer Harold Penketh, a Brighton native, tragically died without bailing out. The aircraft's remains, identified as a Spitfire, were discovered following a geophysical survey of the site. There is an expectation that the salvaged components will eventually be exhibited publicly. Although the precise cause of the crash was never definitively determined, eyewitnesses reported that the Mk 1A Spitfire, serial number X4583, broke away from its formation and plunged nose-first into agricultural land in the village of Holme, located south of Peterborough. An investigation concluded that either the pilot's oxygen supply system failed or the aircraft itself experienced a structural malfunction. The 20-year-old Pilot Officer Penketh apparently made no attempt to deploy his parachute. His body was recovered from the debris and subsequently returned to his relatives. John Bliss, an eyewitness who was a child at the time, recounted that the "enormous crater" formed by the Spitfire's impact rapidly filled with water due to the area's high water table. For 75 years, the Spitfire's wreckage lay submerged in its watery resting place. Cranfield University successfully located the crash site in August, using a combination of a geophysical survey and metal detection. The excavation, commencing on Monday and anticipated to last a week, is being overseen by Oxford Archaeology East.
